answers.text:
Click thumbs up for Arizona State University!

answers.author: Karen Pinkos
answers.text:
With all due respect to some of my colleagues...an MPA will not teach you to be a city, county, or town manager.  Don't get me wrong, you need to have a graduate degree:  it is an important and even necessary step in this business.  And yes, many MPA programs (not just the ones mentioned here) offer wonderful alumni networks, internship programs, alliances with this or that organization which might help you get that first job.
But what counts the most in the hiring process is your work experience (and not just local government experience, either), your drive to succeed, your responsibility to your professional development, and your willingness to work your butt off.  The name on your degree really won't matter unless you have an alum (or enemy of) your school on the panel hiring you!
My MPA is from the great Oakland University in Rochester, Michigan.  It's a WONDERFUL program that I'm sure many of you have never heard of and I have no idea if it's even ranked...and I think I've done pretty well career-wise!  Again, it's your professional development, not your degree, that will ensure your success.  So go with your gut as to which program you feel fits YOU best, and then get to work! Good luck!

answers.author: Susan Thorpe
answers.text:
As a 4 1/2 year resident of Arizona, I have come to know the outstanding reputation that the ASU MPA program has developed. The students have most recently been focused on local government and non-profit management. I am not familiar with other programs, but I'd be remiss if I didn't mention my alma mater, the University of North Texas MPA program (which I believe is ranked very high nationally).  UNT has a great program and a fantastic alumni-student network that can be very helpful in career planning. We are beginning an effort to create a stronger alumni/local manager/student network here too, so perhaps by the time you start school at ASU, it would be up and running.  Good luck with your choice. It's a great profession!!!

We are beginning an effort to create a stronger alumni/local manager/student network here too, so perhaps by the time you start school at ASU, it would be up and running.  Good luck with your choice. It's a great profession!!!

answers.author: David Branscome
answers.text:
I won't hold any of the schools over another, but one thing to think about.  What level of government do you want to go into?  If you're thinking about Federal then I'd recommend American, but if you're most interested in Local Gov then ASU has a lot of really good people and programs these days.  I'd take a good look at the ASU option.


I won't hold any of the schools over another, but one thing to think about.  What level of government do you want to go into? I'd take a good look at the ASU option.

answers.author: Deborah Thalasitis
answers.text:
MPA programs may have different focus areas at different schools, regardless of ranking.  They may be stronger in one area than another.  Some have a strong connection to the non-profit world, some to local government (city management) and some to more global policy studies.  You may want to find out where alumni are typically employed from the schools you are considering (i.e. what are they doing).  You may also want to look at the type of internship experiences that may be leveraged from your school of choice.  Do they have formal programs for internship in local government?  Finally, you may want to look at the relationship the school has to local government manager's in the area or nationally.  As an example, ASU is affiliated with the Alliance.

answers.author: Daniel Ortiz-Hernandez
answers.text:
Ironically when I applied to grad school those were my top three choices. I had the same ambitions as you and ended up going with Arizona State University and it was the best decision I made. My perspective was that each seemed differed in their emphasis but Arizona State has a strong concentration in urban management and strong professional affiliation. Feel free to contact me directly if you'd like to know details of my decision and experience.

answers.author: William Emerson
answers.text:
ASU is a good choice for a municipal government career.  It has a good balance of theory and practice, with innovative leadership at the school.  Arizona is a solidly council-manager state, so ICMA values and practices are common in its cities and towns.

answers.author: Theodore Voorhees
answers.text:
I think Deborah and Willie have some good advice.  Consider where you want to work when you are done since contacts and internships may be your best opening to an actual job.  Look at where students end up after graduation and what courses the school offers to determine their emphasis - federal, state, local.
George Mason has an excellent program, but had a more federal focus when I attended.  American clearly had a federal and international focus when I attended for undergraduate.  I spend a little time at UNC-Chapel Hill these days and they have a significant local emphasis among their other offerings.
All are excellent programs.

I spend a little time at UNC-Chapel Hill these days and they have a significant local emphasis among their other offerings.

All are excellent programs.

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
I'd go a step further and say the rankings won't really mean much of anything for the job you're looking for. If you want to be a town manager, you'll be hired by a council full of people who could care less where your university ranks. THey want to know that you do have an MPA from someplace, and that you have good work experience. 
Choose a college that's located someplace with a lot of internship and entry level opportunities. Avoid the northeast, because there's very little county government and the towns are very static with few middle manager positions and a lot of value placed on who you know, so you're either an admin assistant or you're running a department or three. I had a very hard time breaking through into local government in CT after I got my MPA.  
Consider Bonnie's advice about going to Virginia... I know there are a lot of opportunities for young government professionals in that area. Arizona is like a high-risk stock... a lot of opportunity for growth, but also lots of opportunity for collapse. But overall my advice is to make sure there are a lot of opportunities for work both during and right after college, and intern as much as you can!!! 
If I could go back, I'd have traded in my straight A's for a more rigorous internship in a heartbeat. That work experience is really all these elected bodies will be looking for, so stock up on it as much as possible!
Best of luck!

answers.author: Daniel Koch
answers.text:
We can all post how great a certain school is. For colleges, I always picked what felt right to me.  Don't worry about what school your degree is from, worry about how your work ethic and your abilities will get you there.   If you are going to live in Tempe, then ASU gives you something FSU doesn't, a large metro with many public entities.  Follow your heart, the rest will fall into place.

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Anonymous - this is a great question.  I think that you'll be well served at any of those fine institutions.  I don't know much about them, but I do know that going to one school over another will not determine the trajectory of your career path.  It's a bit of a cliche, but you'll get out of the program what you put into it (and I'm not talking about tuition costs!).  I think any of those alternatives would be a fine environment for you to jump start your career.
I would be remiss if I didn't promote my alma mater, The University of Georgia.  Have you considered attending school here?  It's a very highly regarded program and I felt that it prepared me well.  Also, Athens is a great community to live in while you study.  I finished the program in two years and I was accepted as an ICMA Fellow upon graduation.  I now hold a full time position as an Assistant to the City Manager of a small to medium city in North West Georgia (about 2 years after graduating).  http://padp.uga.edu/
Good luck and let us know when you make a decision!

Good luck and let us know when you make a decision!

answers.author: Kevin Carter
answers.text:
As an undergraduate alumni of American University, let me present a couple points (these are my solely my opinions):
1) the 10k more is only counting tuition and not the insanely high cost of living (expect 1k/month in rent for a studio anywhere in DC).
2) Most of the classes you'll be taking will be with students primarily interested in working on the federal level with professors from federal backgrounds. 
3) However, at AU, you can take advantage of the DC consortium http://www.consortium.org/consortium/index.cfm/college-access/ to take classes at George Washington (where Ron Carlee teaches), Georgetown, George Mason or any of the other DC schools.
4) ASU and FSU are big name schools (primarily due to sports). And although other managers will probably recognize AU, I'm not sure how many councils (i.e. your employer) will. 
5) However DC is a fun city with loads of opportunities.
I would be curious as to how managers look at the importance of schools when hiring, or whether name is irrelevant. All that said, I originally planned to earn my MPA at AU and actually completed a semester’s worth of credits towards it, but I ended up going elsewhere for an MA in American Government over the MPA.


As an undergraduate alumni of American University, let me present a couple points (these are my solely my opinions):

1) the 10k more is only counting tuition and not the insanely high cost of living (expect 1k/month in rent for a studio anywhere in DC).

2) Most of the classes you'll be taking will be with students primarily interested in working on the federal level with professors from federal backgrounds. 

3) However, at AU, you can take advantage of the DC consortium http://www.consortium.org/consortium/index.cfm/college-access/ to take classes at George Washington (where Ron Carlee teaches), Georgetown, George Mason or any of the other DC schools.

4) ASU and FSU are big name schools (primarily due to sports). And although other managers will probably recognize AU, I'm not sure how many councils (i.e. your employer) will. 

5) However DC is a fun city with loads of opportunities.

I would be curious as to how managers look at the importance of schools when hiring, or whether name is irrelevant. All that said, I originally planned to earn my MPA at AU and actually completed a semester’s worth of credits towards it, but I ended up going elsewhere for an MA in American Government over the MPA.

answers.author: Robin Weaver
answers.text:
Since you want to work in local government, Northern Illinois University and Kansas University are excellent choices.  The internship at NIU (my alma mater)  is typically part time with a local government over the entire length of the graduate program.  That way you are present at work for all seasons and will be able to contribute to the organization in more ways due to the length of the experience.  That length of time also provides the student with more time to see how their class topics fit into the real work world.

That length of time also provides the student with more time to see how their class topics fit into the real work world.

answers.author: Willie Best
answers.text:
I am a graduate of American University 1981.  I thought it was expensive back then...$10,000.   I am have been both a city manager and a county manager and assistants in both governments.  If you are looking to begin a career in the Federal Government or non-profit...American is a great choice.  If local government is primary the other universities may offer better connections.  I returned to NC after graduation and returned to the Northern Virgina/Washington, DC area just to asses how it would be to be employed there without being a poor graduate student.  The connections at American were the best.  American University is a  university with high powered professors, many who had worked in the Federal Government and many notable public appointees who came over to the University to speak to the graduate students.  I can honestly say there is no place like going to graduate school in Washington, DC.  It's a powerful place to be.  I wish you the best.

I can honestly say there is no place like going to graduate school in Washington, DC.  It's a powerful place to be.  I wish you the best.

answers.author: Zane Reynolds
answers.text:
Brian Wolverton is exactly right. These national rankings in and of themselves, will not really mean anything after your first year out of grad school. What you really need to be concerned about is the location of the program. So much of entering a career in local government is going to be about networking and experiences. Nationally ranked schools can assist you in this arena, but ultimately it is going to up to you. 
Really think about where geographically you want to end up and start looking at schools in that area. Once you start classes, really get involved in the city and start interning. Many current city managers started off as interns in their current jurisdictions.
I am not saying that NIU and KU will not prepare you well for a career in local government, but really think about the amount of intern and career opportunities that surround Lawrence, KS and De Kalb, IL. ASU may have been a really good option historically, there are many small jurisdictions offering opportunities that surround Mesa. However, Arizona is one place where local governments have been hit extremely hard; many current employees in these jurisdictions have to take up to two weeks unpaid furlough every year. I would be a little apprehensive about how quickly you expect local government opportunities to return to Arizona. 
I am one year out of grad school and already I have interviewed for a position to be a city manager. I can tell you that during my interview, not once was my educational experience even mentioned. The council was far more concerned with my real world experience dealing with the management systems and day to day operation of a municipality.

The council was far more concerned with my real world experience dealing with the management systems and day to day operation of a municipality.

answers.author: Robert Hanna
answers.text:
Choose a school based on the level of government you want to pursue. There are great federal government school that don't do too well in local government. Next, choose a school close to where you want to settle for a career... at least for the first five years. Your internship will help you land your first job and this is an critical component to a quality MPA program. Finally, don't make the mistake of thinking that ranking determine quality of education... BUT do realize that a grad's school alumni network is very helpful in landing that first job.
Good luck in your search and be proud of choosing a career of service. It is a wonderful and rewarding profession.

Good luck in your search and be proud of choosing a career of service. It is a wonderful and rewarding profession.

answers.author: Natasha Nau
answers.text:
I posted this question...I don't know how it posted Anonymously. Thank you so much to everyone who took the time to respond. Your answers were timely and EXTREMELY helpful. I have decided to reply with a "No" to American. I wish I could apply to some of the schools that all of you mentioned but I applied for the fall semester and time is running out. 
I was between FSU and ASU while reading your comments and have ultimately decided to go with ASU. I feel that it can offer me the best education for city/urban management for the best cost. From who I have spoken to on the phone from this forum as well as others in AZ, it seems as though ASU offers excellent internship and networking experiences.
While I unfortunately have no idea where I want to end up because I am only 22 and haven't experienced much of the U.S. yet, I feel as though AZ will be a new and exciting experience. I have consistently been told by professors and city managers that work experience matters more than the name of the school. However, my parents are very concerned with ranking and quality. I plan to take advantage of every opportunity that comes along my way while there as well as diligently making contacts along the way.
Thank you to everyone again for your help. It is truly appreciated!!
Sincerely,
Natasha

answers.author: Gregory Streib
answers.text:
I agree that you can get what you need anywhere, but if you have some freedom of choice, then you should know that all MPA (and MPP) programs are not the same. They are shaped primarily by their locations, their relative importance in their universities, and their faculty. The US News ratings do tend to highlight those programs that are valued because they receive the resources needed to compete. As noted above, give some thought to where you would like to live and look for commitments to topics you care about. Assume nothing. Full disclosure--I am an NIU grad. The environs are sparse, but the the Chicago metro area is busting with possibilities, the MPA program is valued there, and the faculty are committed to public management and local government. Choose nothing less.

They are shaped primarily by their locations, their relative importance in their universities, and their faculty. As noted above, give some thought to where you would like to live and look for commitments to topics you care about. Assume nothing. Full disclosure--I am an NIU grad. The environs are sparse, but the the Chicago metro area is busting with possibilities, the MPA program is valued there, and the faculty are committed to public management and local government. Choose nothing less.

answers.author: John Manahan
answers.text:
If you want to go into city or county management, you should be looking at the University of Kansas (my alma mater) or Northern Illinois University. KU is extremely strong in city and county management. The department typically arranges part time internships with area local governments while you're in school, which helps provide the practical to go along the the theory and gives you some very practical experience to add to your resume. KU alums are in city and county management nationwide, which makes for a pretty good network for full time internships and positions after graduate school.

KU alums are in city and county management nationwide, which makes for a pretty good network for full time internships and positions after graduate school.

author: [Anonymous]
text:
I am trying to decide between three graduate schools for my MPA. American University, Arizona State University, and Florida State University. American is ranked 14th for their MPA program (nationally by US News Weekly), ASU is 25th, and FSU is 27th. However, American costs $10,000 more than the other two schools. Is paying that much more for a school that is only ranked 10 spots higher worth it in the eyes of prospective employers?
If I narrow my options down to ASU and FSU, which school would you recommend? My career goal is to become a county, city, or town manager and I want my education to benefit me as much as possible.
title: Graduate School Choices
